In Japan, the feudal system, known as the Bakufu system, was centered around the samurai class, who were warriors and not necessarily tied to the land in the same way as serfs in medieval England. The Japanese feudal system was more about military service and land grants, rather than a system of personal servitude.

In England, serfdom was a system where peasants were bound to the land and had limited rights. They were often required to work on the lord's land in exchange for protection and basic necessities. The status of serfs in England was generally lower than that of the nobility but higher than that of free peasants.

Given these differences, it would be inaccurate to say that Japanese serfdom had a higher status than English serfdom. The Japanese feudal system, while involving a form of dependency, was structured differently and did not have the same level of personal servitude as English serfdom.
